content: How can I help you today?

Honestly, I'm not sure how this is supposed to help. I've just been so wound up lately, not sleeping, and constantly worrying about work. My partner pushed me to come here, so I guess I’m giving it a shot, but I’m not convinced talking will fix anything.

Thank you for sharing that—it sounds like you're going through a tough time right now. Feeling wound up, struggling to sleep, and worrying about work can be really overwhelming, and it’s understandable to have doubts about how talking might help. It’s great that you’ve taken this step to explore it, even if you’re unsure. What’s been weighing on you the most lately?

Honestly, it's the fear of losing my job. Work's been stressful, and with the way the company’s doing, I feel like there's a target on my back. I keep thinking about how I’d provide for my family if that happened, and it’s just all-consuming.

That sounds like a lot. The fear of losing your job and worrying about providing for your family must feel really heavy, especially when it feels like the stress is ever-present. It’s understandable for those kinds of thoughts to take over. How long has this worry been building for you?

It's been a few months now, I think. Things started feeling shaky at work when the company began hinting at possible layoffs, and it's only gotten worse as the stock market has dipped. Every day, I feel like I'm walking on eggshells.

It sounds like those months have been really difficult, carrying the uncertainty and pressure every day. Walking on eggshells like that can make it hard to focus on anything else. With everything that’s been going on, have you had any moments where you felt like you could take a step back and catch your breath?

Not really, to be honest. My mind just doesn’t stop—it’s like this constant loop of “what ifs.” Even when I’m with my family, I’ll catch myself zoned out and worrying instead of actually being present with them. It’s just exhausting.

It sounds exhausting to be caught in that constant cycle, worrying so much that it’s hard to be fully present even during moments with your family. You care deeply about providing for them, and that must add to the weight of everything. What helps you cope, even a little, when you’re feeling overwhelmed like this?

Usually, I just distract myself with work or scrolling on my phone, but honestly, that doesn’t really help for long. Other than that, I haven’t really found a way to cope—I just kind of push through it. It’s like I’m stuck in this loop, and I don’t know how to break out of it.

Pushing through without much relief sounds draining, and it shows resilience to keep managing day to day even when feeling stuck. It sounds like you’ve been relying on distraction or diving deeper into work. How does that leave you feeling afterward?

Honestly, it doesn’t help much. Working more just adds to the stress, and scrolling on my phone makes me feel like I’m wasting time. It’s like I’m trying to outrun my thoughts, but they’re always there waiting for me.

It sounds like those strategies haven’t given you the relief you’re looking for—trying to escape the thoughts only to find them still there must feel discouraging. It makes sense why you'd try to cope this way, given how much you’ve been carrying. What kind of relief or change would you hope for, even if it feels out of reach right now?

I guess I’d just want to feel calm for once, like my brain isn’t running on overdrive all the time. Being able to sleep and actually enjoy time with my family without worrying about work would be amazing. I just don’t know how to get there.

Wanting calm and being able to enjoy time with your family without those constant worries sounds like a meaningful goal—it shows how much you value peace of mind and those family moments. Not knowing how to get there can feel daunting, but recognizing what you’re hoping for is an important first step. What do you think has made it hard to find that calm lately?

I think it's because I can't stop thinking about the "what ifs." I’m always running scenarios through my head about work—what’ll happen if I lose my job, if I can’t pay the bills. It just feels like there’s no way to shut off those thoughts.

It sounds like those "what ifs" have been dominating your thoughts, keeping you trapped in a cycle of worry. Constantly imagining worst-case scenarios is draining, and it makes sense why it’s felt hard to shut them off. Do you ever find moments, even briefly, where you feel more present or less caught up in those thoughts?
Not really, no. Even in the few moments I try to relax, those thoughts always seem to creep back in. It's like they never really leave me alone, even when I want to focus on something else.

That sounds really challenging, not being able to fully relax or find relief from those intrusive thoughts. Feeling like they’re always there must add to the frustration and exhaustion. Is there anything you’d be open to exploring that might help create even small moments of calm?

I'm not sure what would help, to be honest. I’ve never really done anything like this before, and it’s hard to imagine something working when my mind is always racing. But I guess I’m here, so I’m willing to hear what you think might help.

Thank you for being open to exploring, even though it feels hard to imagine right now—being here and willing to consider possibilities shows courage. To get a clearer sense of things, would you like to review any of your step count, sleep, or resting heart rate data together? Sometimes looking at that can offer insights into patterns that might connect to how you’re feeling.
